results.title: Birds that never fly
results.creator_credit: Harold J. Pollock and Bank of New South Wales
results.brief_description: This film deals with the flightless birds of Australia and New Zealand: the emu, cassowary, kiwi and the extinct moa. It shows their physical characteristics, breeding and eating habits. Narrated by John Dease. Suitable for upper secondary level.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Harold J. Pollock and Bank of New South Wales

results.title: Birds that eat insects
results.brief_description: Explains how the physical structure of birds is adapted to the kind of food they eat. Draws attention to the strong wings and wide bills of birds that chase insects in the air; the small size and agility of birds that hunt in bushes; and the strong chisel-shaped bill of wood-peckers. Shows the swallow, nighthawk, kingbird chestnut -sided warbler, black-billed cuckoo, white-breasted nuthatch, flicker, robin, bluebird, housewren, and hairy, downy and redheaded woodpeckers. No other credits available.

results.title: Birds that eat flesh
results.brief_description: Explains how the physical structure of birds is adapted to the food they eat. Shows members of the hawk family, which hunt by day, and calls attention to their strong wings, talons, and sharp hooked bill. Shows night hunters which have the sharp hooked bill and powerful large talons of the hawks. Explains that they rely on keen night vision and sensitive hearing to locate prey, and draws attention to the soft downy feathers on wing tips which make flight noiseless. No other credits available.

results.title: Birds that eat fish
results.brief_description: Explains how the physical structure of birds is adapted to the kind of food they eat. Draws attention to the long sharp bill, long toes and legs to support wading birds like the heron, the strong sharp pointed bill of the kingfisher which plunges into water to seize fish in its beak, the strong wings, legs, and talons of the osprey which glides in the air then drops into water to seize fish in its talons.

results.title: Birds of the tide
results.brief_description: Tidal flats, exposed at low tide on Westernport bay, support vegetation which harbours small marine life. They provide in turn, the feeding grounds for a large variety of birds. Inland from these grounds lies Rhyll Swamp, a protected area which is an important breeding ground for such species of bird as the Royal Spoonbill and White hen. The film looks at the influence of tides on wading and fishing birds and shows them in their nesting colonies in Rhyll Swamp. Filmed by Art Mayer and Graham Pizzey. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Birds of the prairie marshes
results.brief_description: This film studies several species of wild ducks, geese and other waterfowl - some reared in permanent captivity, others transient seasonal visitors to the Delta Waterfowl Research Station on one of the largest marsh areas on the shore of Lake Manitoba. From the constant parade of wild fowl swimming about on the Station’s ponds, for the camera singles out individual birds for close observation while the commentary discusses their behaviour, nesting and migratory habits, and range in North America. No other credits available.

results.title: Birds of prey
results.creator_credit: ERPI Classroom Films and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Studies the development and habitats of American owls, vultures, eagles, hawks and includes scenes of hunting, nesting and feeding of the young. No other credits available.

results.title: Birds of a feather
results.creator_credit: Terri Loewy, Nick Bosustow and Stephen Bosustow Productions
results.brief_description: An animated cartoon which focuses on the concept of nonconformity by telling a story about a bored, dejected bird, which, attracted by the beautiful plumes of a passerby’s hat, seizes the feathers, and proudly assumes a new appearance.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Terri Loewy, Nick Bosustow and Stephen Bosustow Productions

results.title: Birds - how we identify them
results.brief_description: Accompanies two boys looking for birds. With field glasses and bird guide book, they see and identify many different birds. Demonstrates how to distinguish one bird from another, by their appearance, by the sounds they make, and their actions, both on the ground and in the air. The identifying characteristics of many more birds are pointed out as they are observed in their natural habitat. No other credits available.

results.title: Birds and their characteristics
results.brief_description: Shows in detail the characteristics which differentiate birds from the other groups of vertebrates-feathers, wings and legs, warm-bloodedness and beaks. Demonstrates the adaptations and special characteristics of several kinds of birds, and shows details of a bird’s flight using slow-motion photography. No other credits available.
